content:
What OS are you using ? What version of Thunderbird are you using?

Where did you get the download/install of Thunderbird? Did you get it from eg: Windows App Store, Snap, Flatpak or somewhere else ? Or download from official website : https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ Or is it a 'portable Thunderbird' ?

Are emails in a Pop or Imap account? Do you download full copies or just headers? Do you have the profile folders in the standard default location or somewhere else like on OneDrive or NAS etc ?

I ask those questions because it sounds like the emails are not immediately available - as if there is a link to them.

re :I'm unable to select "Reply," I presume you are right click on email in Message List and select clicking on the top level set of icons - the second icon in from the left.

If threading is enabled and you right click on a collapsed thread then 'Reply' etc is not an available item.

I'm using 'Thunderbird Extended Support Release' (ESR) version 128.8.1esr 64bit also testing in Beta 137.0b3 I'm not having any problem regardless of whether Message Pane is open or not.
creator: Toad-Hall

Most web hosts offer secure and insecure settings options that are posted in their cpanel components. Thank you.

content:
For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: What you are doing is what I routinely recommend. When you copy IMAP messages, you are really downloading to PC and then uploading to the other IMAP account, yet IMAP was never designed for large uploads. The concurrent download and upload puts a strain on thunderbird. By separating the tasks, as you do with 'save as', you reduce the load.
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you David. Even if it is the procedure is correct and recommended, I would like to simplify it by making it possible to transfer the message directly into Thunderbird. What I'm asking is: is there a way within Thunderbird, for example a different setup of the configuration parameters, to allow transfering of an email with attachment from one account to another?
creator: l.amodei

content: What I am trying to communicate is that thunderbird is forced to deal with the internet connections to do what you want. Thunderbird sends the requests to the servers, but thunderbird cannot control the servers.

david said
What you are doing is what I routinely recommend. When you copy IMAP messages, you are really downloading to PC and then uploading to the other IMAP account, yet IMAP was never designed for large uploads. The concurrent download and upload puts a strain on thunderbird. By separating the tasks, as you do with 'save as', you reduce the load.

creator: skypilot65

content: As I mentioned to the other individual, the email client tasked with the work isn't the problem; the problem is the immensity of the task at hand. Moving large amounts of data across the network to a protocol (IMAP) that was never designed to be the recipient, is difficult. The server is more likely to stumble than the email client.
creator: davidsk

content: Well, you could change the synchronization&storage to just sync most recent 30 days. All you need are the headers to retrieve other messages. If a large number are just history, those could be kept in a separate folder. The challenge we all face is that keeping everything in one folder puts a strain on all resources. Another option is to download history items. Another option is to pay for premium server support. Everything becomes a compromise. :)

content: Please understand that Thunderbird is just an agent; the rejection of your password is a message transmitted to you by thunderbird that comes from your email provider. You can access and change or delete the password by going to settings>privacy&security, clicking savedpasswords and then showpasswords. My suggestion is to then delete the rows for that account and click to get messages. At that point, thunderbird has no password on file, so you should be then prompted.

content:
How do you know it's not going to the recipient? If you entered a 'TO' email address and it wasn't your email address then it went to the recipient. However, a copy may have been sent to yourself if you Cc'd yourself in any emails your sent.

In Account Settings Select 'Copies & Folders' for the effected account Under 'when sending messages....' Did you select the 'Cc' or 'Bcc' checkbox and input your own email address ? This would mean you get sent a copy of the email.

creator: davidsk

content: I thought I had explained. You're not an AI bot, are you? It is a commonly recommended procedure for transferring emails in bulk between Gmail accounts to use Takeout to download a huge mbox (or separate labels), copy the mbox into .thunderbird/<profile>/Mail/Local Folders, then use Thunderbird to move them into the new account by IMAP. The only import available in Gmail uses POP3 and is highly unreliable and unsupported. I used this procedure to move out of my Google Workspace domain in 2021 when it became no longer free and again in 2023 when free account email storage became included in the free 15G allowance. I divided my historical emails 1988-2016 in one account and 2017-2025 in another. This year I had to move the boundary from 2015 to 2017 and I have only Android and Chromebook available. Thunderbird is failing in Crostini, which I have reported as a bug.
creator: myatescbk

content: No, no bot. From your post, i infer you use chromebook as the desktop to upload messages to gmail. If you're uploading to an email account, I don't see the need for a separate storage (Local Folders) on the phone. Thunderbird needs an account to move messages to, not a fixed location on a phone.
creator: davidsk

content: To repeat, the one feature which keeps me and I'm sure many others using Thunderbird is its handling of mbox files. This is missing from the Android app, which seems to be just a re-branding of Kmail, which IMHO should not be allowed by the Mozilla Foundation, who should have adopted Kmail with its name. The feature could easily be added, even improved by putting Local Folders in, say, storage/emulated/0/Thunderbird.
creator: myatescbk

content:
Problem solved. My error, but I want to describe what I did wrong, since others might have the same issue from the same mistake.

In the "Quick Filter Toolbar", I'd accidentally clicked the button "Keep filters applied when switching folders". Since no filters were entered in the "Filter messages..." field, the search came up empty in every folder I tried -- and said "No message found". As soon as I unclicked that button, all the messages showed up again.

Hope this solves a problem for someone else down the line.
creator: borisgoodenough

content:
Probably a corrupted prefs.js file. This happens when Thunderbird oder PC crash or by a short a blowout. Thunderbird creates a new virgin prefs.js file which doesn't contain any of your account settings.

Go to Help < Troubleshooting Information < Profile Folder > Open folder. In the profile folder xxxxxxxx. default (or similar name) look for a prefs-1.js file or invalidprefs.js file. Also look up the prefs.js and note its size. Tell us also whether you have a recent backup of your Thunderbird profile
creator: Mapenzi

creator: Radan

content:
Your screenshot shows a prefs.js file from March 26th, it has a size of kB which is the size of a "virgin" newly created prefs.js file which doesn't contain your account data.

I propose to restart TB and create your verizon.net POP account. After that go to Account settings > verizon account >Server-Settings > Message Storage > Local Directory and click on "Browse....". (see my screenshot) Navigate to your old verizon "pop3.xxxxx.net" account folder which is located in ...\Profiles\xxxxxxxx.default\Mail\ , select the "pop3.xxxxx.net" folder and click "Open". Now TB will ask you to restart, do that and you should see folders and messages of your verizon account.

If you also used the Local Folders to store messages we'll have to repeat the same operation for Local Folders..
creator: Mapenzi

content: before I start fiddling with settings - as you know, verizon.net mail is a pop3 by design; nevertheless I can get the same email on different devices, one by one (two laptops-Windows and Linux , iphone mail app) which points at imap. Aol/verizon settings are imap.aol.com for incoming and smtp.verizon.net for outgoing. Can I still proceed as you are suggesting? I am lost...
creator: Radan

content: First you must understand that POP accounts store their messages in account folders such as "pop3.verizon.net" in the"Mail" folder of the Thunderbird profile folder (or as shown in my screenshot pop.free.fr) Since your prefs.js file went corrupt you had to re-create the account for your verizon email address. So a new account folder "pop3.verizon-1.net" has been created in folder "Mail", but it contains only the last messages which still were on the server. But you want to see all your old messages which are stored in the "pop3.verizon.net" folder. What I described is how to "link" your newly created POP account with the old local directory (account folder) by choosing the local directory "pop3.verizon.net" instead of "pop3.verizon-1.net" via Server-Settings > Message Storage > local directory >>> Browse....

content:
Ok, it's what I'd said before. When your "Thunderbird account vanished" - as you related in your first message - and you re-created the vanished account, you created the new account as an IMAP account although it formerly was a POP account. So it is normal that you cannot see the old messages of this account since they are stored in the pop.verizon.net account folder in the Folder "Mail". There are at least two methods to restore those messages.

I'll explain the more simple way: ‚Ä¢ open Account Settings, click on "New Account" and create once more your verizon account but this time pay attention to choose the POP protocol ‚Ä¢ if the account is successfully created as a POP account go to Server Settings > Message Storage > local folder and click on "Browse...." ‚Ä¢ navigate to your profile folder > Mail > select the pop.verizon.net folder and click on "Open". ‚Ä¢ You will be prompted to restart Thunderbird and thereafter you should see your verizon POP account in the folder pane. And you should the old messages of this account....
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Since you use the IMAP protocol on different devices it would be a better solution to keep your actual Verizon address as an IMAP account. To recover the old messages still lying dormant in the pop.verizon.net account folder in Mail I propose the following different solution: ‚Ä¢ Thunderbird closed, go to the Mail folder in your profile and copy the pop.verizon.net account folder ‚Ä¢ paste it in Local Folders-1 and rename it in Verizon.sbd ‚Ä¢ open Notepad, save the empty file as Verizon and delete the .txt suffix which will be added automatically by your Windows system ‚Ä¢ move the Verizon file in Local Folders-1 ‚Ä¢ Now you should see somewhat like in my screen shot below in your Local Folders-1 ‚Ä¢ Restart Thunderbird and look up Local Folders in the folder pane: you should see the folders and messages from your old verizon POP account (see second image)

If you like you can copy the old messages to the corresponding folders in your actual Verizon IMAP account

content: Your screenshot is OK with the Verizon.sbd folder in Local Fodlers. But Thunderbird can only display the subfolders in Verizon.sbd if it is paired with a so-called mailbox file which is a text file having the same name without any file extension. This missing file "Verizon" can be created with a text editor such as Notepad: open Notepad and without writing any text in the file save it under the name "Verizon". Take care to delete the .txt file extension and move the Verizon file in Local Folders. Once again if it is too difficult to understand: "Verizon" is an empty text file

I found a way to resolve this. It could not be done with TB.

creator: jseliga24

content:
The problem is that your e-mail account was removed from the server. Two kinds of things can be done to recover your messages:

  1. Was a copy of your account on the server made? If so, it can be restored. Apparently, though, no copy was made. If it had been made, the IT person would be restoring it. But it would be strange if there were no copy. Before making big changes on the server, the IT person would want a copy of the files in their original state. Doesn't the IT person have such a copy? Why aren't they using it to restore your account?
  1. Was a copy of the files on your computer (client) made? In that .file file? In any other way (did you ever back up the files on your computer?)? If so, your e-mail files can be restored, though you must be careful how you do that. To know whether or not this can be done, you have to know whether or not the back-up that you have is a copy from your computer or from the server. If it is from your computer, then you have to know how to work with the back-up file. That usually entails knowing which software made the back-up. You have to know how to open the back-up file and get at the contents. Or you have to find some other copy of your computer's files. The .file extension seems to be a generic extension that does not tell us which application created it.

Thunderbird is not yet relevant in either scenario, but will become relevant if you have a back-up copy that you can work with.

content:
Is Thunderbird still installed on your computer? With the profile that you want to use?

Close Thunderbird.

I would copy all the e-mail files that you want to keep (sent, precision, etc.) without the companion .msf files, into ‚ÄúLocal folders‚Äù in your current Thunderbird profile.

Then, when you connect Thunderbird to your re-established account on a server, they will not be affected. You can move the messages back to a server later if you want.

Open Thunderbird. It will need some time to index the new files. Your restored messages will be in Local Folders.

In your place, I might also wait for others to comment on this approach in case they have better ideas. But copying files into your local folders is pretty safe.

And start a regular back-up regimen?

content:
Probably a corrupted prefs.js file. This happens when Thunderbird oder PC crash or by a short a blowout. Thunderbird creates a new virgin prefs.js file which doesn't contain any of your account settings.

Go to Help < Troubleshooting Information < Profile Folder > Open folder. In the profile folder xxxxxxxx. default (or similar name) look for a prefs-1.js file or invalidprefs.js file. Also look up the prefs.js and note its size. Tell us also whether you have a recent backup of your Thunderbird profile

The prefs.js is 13K and that was the only prefs. file listed, but in the Crashes folder is shows a crash today.
creator: quiltjunkie2002

content:
Your actual prefs.js file is a bit bigger than a virgin prefs.js file (7 kB) since you already have re-set up your account. I guess that your account is set using the POP protocol since otherwise it would have downloaded all messages, sent and received....

I suggest to go to Account settings > your account >Server-Settings > Message Storage > Local Directory and click on "Browse....". (see my screenshot) Navigate to your old "pop3.xxxxx.xx" account folder which is located in ...\Profiles\xxxxxxxx.default\Mail\ , select the "pop3.xxxxx.xx" folder and click "Open". Now TB will ask you to restart, do that and you should see folders and messages of your pop account.

If you also used the Local Folders to store messages we'll have to repeat the same operation for Local Folders..

creator: Mapenzi

content:
Thunderbird acct disappeared Mapenzi Mar 28, 2025, 1:08:01‚ÄØAM

Thanks for the last image. In the meantime I reviewed all your screenshots and realised that my first diagnosis - a corrupt prefs.js file - was erroneous. What really has happened is that Thunderbird for an unknown reason had created a new virgin profile! Your old profile is named 7hcals8w.default whereas the new profile is named f5p22zq3.default-release. Actually you are working in the new profile, your accounts and messages are in the old profile. Please confirm by a screenshot with the contents of the "Profiles" folder in Thunderbird. In the Thunderbird folder you'll also see a profiles.ini file, please open it with a text editor and make a screen shot of its contents

So your reply's are not showing up here, so that's why I'm copying from your emails...here are the screen shots, one from the old data dir, one from the new that TB is using and the profiles.ini file...
creator: quiltjunkie2002

content:
Excellent screen shots, thanks! They confirm that you have two profiles: the old profile "default" with its profile folder 7hcals8w.default which is actually inactive, and an active virgin profile default-release with its profile folder f5p22zq3.default-release

Since it's the first time in my "helper career" that I notice Thunderbird creating a new profile "ex nihilo" I am not sure whether the old profile is still viable or at least can be resuscitated by the manoeuvre I am going to propose you.

First of all, to be on the secure side: create a backup copy of your "Thunderbird" folder, the one which contains your profiles and all TB data.

Next: the Thunderbird application closed, open the profiles.ini file with Notepad, and in the last paragraph

[General] StartWithLastProfile=1 Version=2

replace the 1 with a 0 (zero) and save the modification.

Now each time you start Thunderbird it will first open the profile manager (image) which invites you to choose between your two profiles to start with: default (old) or default-release (new).

Select your old "default" profile and hit "Start Thunderbird". Now comes the crucial moment: either your old profile is in good shape and TB displays all your accounts, messages, address books, .... or.... we must search for another solution. If you get an error message on TB start up please make a screenshot!
creator: Mapenzi
